chargeHist.descr: Arson of Property Other Than Building

result.execSummary:
The defendant Miles W Hinojosa was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law (Restitution) - $1632.00

State of Wisconsin appears by ADA Nicholas Grode; Defendant appears in person and by Attorney Travis Slattery; FCC Kruse makes statement to amount requested and his calculations; Attorney Slattery makes statement; Attorney Grode agrees with FCC Kruse's calculations; Attorney Slattery and defendant agree upon a restitution amount of $1,632.00; ADA Grode will prepare order; FTR Minutes 11:07:08 thru 11:13:29 am
Defendant Miles W Hinojosa in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery.  Nicholas Grode appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

2:48 Defendant Miles W Hinojosa in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery.  Michael Daniel Zell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Jason Parks is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Zell. He is a detective with the Marshfield Police Department. He was assigned to investigate a car fire in the City of Marshfield on 11/27/14 that was suspicious. He spoke to Officer Hasz, who indicated that there was a hole in the back window of the vehicle. It was believed that the fire started in the middle of the back seat. The vehicle belonged to C.B. There were beer cans and cigarette packs in the driveway. There were also fresh vehicle tracks in the snow. There was a vehicle that Officer Hasz passed on the way to the scene that pulled into a driveway. The driver of that vehicle was identified as the defendant. The witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom. There were beer cans and cigarette packs in his vehicle that matched the same found at the scene. There was a tire iron and baseball bat in the front seat of the vehicle. There were glass shards stuck to the tire iron. The defendant was arrested for OWI. He indicated he knew the victim and was in the driveway of that residence that day waiting for his wife. He indicated that the victim did not like him. Attorney Slattery cross-examines witness. 
Attorney Slattery makes statement and asks Court dismiss case.
Attorney Zell makes statement and asks Court to find probable cause.
Court finds probable cause that a felony was committed and the defendant committed it. Bound over for further proceedings. Bond is continued.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for November 6, 2015 at 09:00 am.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment at 10-08-2015 02:30 pm
No contact with C.B. or residence.
9:45 Defendant Miles W Hinojosa in court.  Craig Lambert appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Bound over for preliminary hearing. Not guilty plea to counts 2 & 3.
